awd_titl_txt: Frameworks: Collaborative Research: Extensible and Community-Driven Thermodynamics, Transport, and Chemical Kinetics Modeling with Cantera: Expanding to Diverse Scientific Domains
awd_abstract_narration:
Modeling and simulation play key enabling roles in aiding and accelerating discovery connecting to energy and chemical research. In applications such as energy storage and conversion, atmospheric chemistry, and catalytic chemical processing, modeling and simulation software helps facilitate technological advances. However, in recent years the available software has not kept pace with the increasing chemical complexity and interdisciplinarity of advanced technology solutions. This project addresses this gap by developing and promoting new state-of-the-art modeling capabilities for diverse scientific fields in the existing Cantera software platform. Cantera is an extensible, open-source framework that enables researchers to study basic science and support new technology development and enables teachers to demonstrate concepts and applications in their classrooms. This project extends Cantera to provide new cross-disciplinary research capabilities and provides a foundation for further community-driven improvements to the Cantera framework. Simultaneous development of the open-source platform and outreach to new user communities will facilitate both fundamental scientific insight and practical technology design and analysis, train the next generation of researchers in both software-development best practices and scientific knowledge, and generate reusable and open educational materials. In addition to work on the framework development, the project includes training of graduate students as well as education, outreach and scientific community engagement activities.


This work will develop the Cantera software platform in service of three objectives: (i) extend Cantera?s scientific capabilities to support the development of transformative technologies; (ii) expand Cantera?s user base in fields including electrochemistry, heterogeneous catalysis, and atmospheric chemistry; and (iii) broaden participation in the software?s development and management to improve Cantera?s sustainability and usability. These will be achieved by developing new scientific modeling capabilities, conducting outreach to new user communities, and improving Cantera?s architecture and software development practices. The new scientific modeling capabilities will focus on four content areas: thermodynamics, chemical kinetics, transport, and multi-phase capabilities. Outreach activities, including publications and presentations, conference workshops, and domain-specific software toolkits with examples to demonstrate Cantera operation and functionality, will engage new and existing communities. The project will establish a scientific advisory board, consisting of experts from diverse fields and backgrounds who will help guide software development and outreach. Finally, the architectural and software engineering changes in this work will improve extensibility and interoperability and implement advanced numerical algorithms to enable the application of Cantera to new types of problems. These changes will also make it easier for users to contribute to Cantera, ensure software correctness, and provide new ways of accessing Cantera?s functionality. The resulting software framework will aid in scientific discovery and development of key enabling technologies with broad societal impacts. These impacts include next-generation batteries and fuel cells for clean energy storage and conversion, catalytic and membrane reactors for electrolysis, novel fuel generation, chemical processing, environmentally conscious combustion applications, and understanding and addressing anthropogenic challenges in atmospheric chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
In this project, new state-of-the-art capabilities were implemented in Cantera, an open-source software platform for modeling chemical kinetics, thermodynamics, and transport processes. These new features have extended Cantera's ability to support modeling in fields such as energy storage and conversion, chemicals processing, and atmospheric chemistry.

Building on Cantera's widespread usage in combustion simulation, new thermodynamic and reaction rate models were implemented to broaden the range of systems that can be modeled using Cantera. These new models include the Peng-Robinson real gas model, which can be used to simulate flames at extremely high pressures; the Blowers-Masel reaction rate model, which allows representing the dependency of activation energies on the thermodynamic properties of the reactants and products; a model for catalytic surfaces that accounts for the effect of each adsorbed species on the thermodynamic properties of other adsorbed species; a model for binary phases using tabulated data as input, which can be used to represent battery materials based on limited experimental data; and a plasma phase where the electron temperature can be decoupled from the temperature of ordinary gas phase species.

A new, extensible file format based on the YAML standard was introduced for providing input data to Cantera and for saving the state of Cantera objects representing species, phases, and reactions. This YAML input format replaces two older input file formats used by Cantera and provides mechanisms which allow users to define their own additional data fields that are preserved and accessible within Cantera. Newly added serialization support enables users to save modified input files which reflect ways in which Cantera objects have been modified as part of a simulation, for example by adding or removing species or reactions from a system. These capabilities enable Cantera to easily interface with other simulation software by using this YAML format as a common interchange format for data describing species thermodynamics and chemical reactions.

This project also introduced a framework for user-defined models of reaction rates and the governing equations of homogeneous reactors. These user models can be written in Python, a language that is accessible to many scientific users, while most of the calculations are still done in Cantera's efficient, compiled C++ core. User-customizable models provide flexibility to represent systems with additional physics beyond what is represented in Cantera's built-in models while still being able to use Cantera's built-in chemical kinetics and thermodynamics models as well as Cantera's robust numerical solvers.

Numerical algorithms that allow efficient computations using kinetic mechanisms with hundreds or thousands of species and reactions were implemented. Such large models are needed to study the evolution of atmospheric pollutants or the combustion of complex fuels. The new sparse preconditioned reactor solver can reduce integration times by up to a factor of 4000 for chemical mechanisms involving thousands of species, with simulations that previously took more than a day completing in less than one minute.

These new capabilities were implemented as part of three major releases of Cantera over the course of this project. In addition to these major features, substantial work was done in these releases to improve the usability and maintainability of the code by increasing the use of modern software engineering best practices such as automated testing and test coverage reporting, migrating to more recent programming language standards, and packaging Cantera for popular distribution channels such as PyPI and Conda Forge. All of Cantera's features are available for use by researchers and engineers in academia, government, and industry under a permissive open-source license.


Last Modified: 04/26/2024
Modified by: Raymond L Speth
